Title: the friendship algorithm

Scene: The apartment. Sheldon is reading one of the questionnaires. He tuts.
Rock climbing centre. Sheldon and Kripke are watching someone descend the practice wall.
Sheldon is seen dangling from the ropes
Raj: Mmm, gentlemen, I put it to you, the worst tapioca pudding is better than the best pudding of any other flavour.
Really? I once saw him shopping at Ralph’s. He was buying tequila.
Don’t feel bad Leonard, negative results are still results.
I’m curious. In the “How Well Do You Know Sheldon” section, what do you put for his favourite amino acid?
Damn it. I had Lysine and changed it.
He almost made it to the top this time.
Sheldon: First off, that is axiomatically wrong, because the best pudding is chocolate. Secondly, the organic structure of tapioca makes it a jiggling bowl of potential death. It is extracted from the plant…
It is extracted from the plant…
Tapioca is extracted from the root of the plant Manihot Esculenta. Due to a high concentration of cyanide it is poisonous in its raw form and lethal if prepared improperly.
It is also indigenous to Brazil, as is the Cocoa Bean, from which we get chocolate, the best pudding. And you promised you wouldn’t do that anymore!

Hey it’s true, Kripke lacks the basic social skills that we take for granted, but he also controls the new open science grid computer that I need to use to run some simulations of structure formation in the early universe.
Well then, the solution is simple. I shall befriend him. Kripke!
What’d you say of the idea of you and I becoming friends?
Really? That seems rather short sighted, coming from someone who is generally considered altogether unlikable. Why don’t you take some time to reconsider?
Well I think we’re off to a terrific start.
First warning.
Hi.
It’s a questionnaire I devised. I’m having some difficulty bonding with a colleague at work, so I’m doing a little research to better understand why my current friends like me.
Yeah, I agree, the social sciences are largely hokum. But, short of putting electrodes in your brain and monitoring your response to my companionship, this is the best I can do.

I know, I may have started off with a fairly obvious one. You did an aspect of my most appealing trait, playfulness. Why don’t you just go ahead and write that number 1. I’m afraid you’re on your own for the rest. It should take you no more than 3 hours.
Only 211. Don’t worry, in deference to you, I’ve kept them on a high school graduate reading level.
You got it, buddy.
Well that’s certainly a thought-provoking hypothesis. May I suggest it as the topic for your essay.
Your questionnaire, very disappointing.
You answered the multiple choice questions in a pattern. A B B A C. A B B A C.
How could I not?
Yes, well it’s better than what Wolowitz did. He drew a raccoon with what appears to be, a distended scrotum.
What hope do I have for establishing new relationships given that my current friends apparently cannot take a few hours out of their lives to help me?
I don’t see how you could.
What do you mean!?
I did learn how to swim.
The skills are transferrable. I just have no interest in going in the water.

The ice caps are melting Leonard. In the future, swimming isn’t going to be optional. But you do bring up an interesting point. I don’t have to break new ground here, I’m sure much of the research already exists.
That’s insane on the face of it. Come on.
You’re driving me to the mall. I’m going to acquire a book that summarizes the current theories in the field of friendmaking.
Coping with the death of a loved one. My condolences.
Family or friend?
Too bad. If it’d been a friend, I’m available to fill the void. (Woman moves away) It’s just as well, she smelled like moth balls.
Excuse me. Do you have any books about making friends?
I assume the skills can be extrapolated and transferred.
Oh! I love trains!
Me too! Most people don’t see it. What are you reading?
Oh I do like monkeys!
Somewhat anthropomorphized but yes. Say, maybe sometime you and I can go see monkeys together. Would you like that?
I’m making friends with this little girl. What’s your name?
Hi Rebecca, I’m your new friend, Sheldon.
We were really hitting it off.
Oh good! You’re just in time. I believe I’ve isolated the algorithm for making friends.
See, my initial approach to Kripke, had the same deficiencies as those that plagued Stu the Cockatoo, when he was new at the zoo.
It’s a terrific book. I’ve distilled its essence into a simple flowchart that would guide me through the process.

Mmhmm. Mmhmm. It’s interesting. But isn’t ventriloquism, by definition, a solo activity? Yeah? Tell me another interest of yours. Hmmm. Is there any chance you like monkeys? What is wrong with you? Everybody likes monkeys. Hang on, Kripke. (Checking changes Howard has made to his flowchart) A loop counter? And an escape to the least objectionable activity! Howard, that’s brilliant! I’m surprised you saw that.

Alright Kripke, that last interest strikes me as the least objectionable and I would like to propose that we do that together. Tomorrow. Yes, I’ll pay. Alright, goodbye. Alright! Time to learn rock climbing.
You know, I am a fan of ventriloquism. Maybe you, me and your dummy could go get a hot beverage. He could talk while you drink.
This appears significantly more monolithic than it did on my laptop. No, one expects to see Hominids learning to use bones as weapeons.
Hardly. Fear of heights is illogical. Fear of falling, on the other hand, is prudent and evolutionary. What would you say is the minimum altitude I need to achieve to cement our new-found friendship?
Little kid Hominids, perhaps. (To man who attaches him to ropes) Is this your entire job? Your parents must be so proud.
Coming, Kripke. Okay. Harness seems to be secure. Small amount of incontinence just now, but the website said that’s to be expected. Hey, this isn’t so bad. A bit like vertical swimming.
I am? I was wrong. It IS a fear of heights.
Not really. I feel somewhat like an inverse tangent function that’s approaching an asymptote.
What part of an inverse tangent function approaching an asymptote did you not understand?
Yeah, I don’t think I can.
No, that doesn’t seem any more likely.
Well, it’s not exactly a plan but I think I’m going to pass out.
Hello, everyone. I brought my new friend, Barry Kripke, home for dinner.
D-d-d! That’s where I sit.
Oh yes, I pass out all the time. But, it was worth it. I’ve made substantial progress in bonding with Kripke, which brings me to an awkward moment.
Maintaining five friendships promises to be a Herculean task. So, I’m going to have to let one of you go.
Leonard, you are my roommate, my source of transportation and you help me fold my sheets when they come out of the dryer. You are safe.
Don’t be silly. Howard, you do not have a PhD, your cologne is an assault on the senses and you’re not available for video games during the Jewish high holidays.
No. You, too, are safe.

Penny, Penny, Penny. Everything you’re saying is true, but please allow me to continue. Raj, you’re out. The good question, while you do provide a certain cultural diversity to an otherwise homogenous group, your responses to the questionnaire were truly disturbing. How could you, for a moment, think that my favourite amino acid is Glutamine?
Yeah. Shoulda, woulda coulda, Raj.
So uh, Kripke, I was wondering if there’s any chance you could get me some time on the open science grid computer.
No? But we’re friends!
I’m confused. I was given an understanding that you allow your friends time on the machine?
Oh. This entire endeavour seems to have been an exercise in futility. Raj, you’re back in. He likes monkeys.
Howard: Hey, I’m thinking of growing a mustache.
I’m not sure yet. You know, George Clooney has one now!
Oh, you’d think a guy like that would have some kind of booze lackey.
C’mon, don’t let him get to you. It’s Kripke.
That’s why he eats by himself, instead of sitting here at the cool table.
Hear him out. If he’s really on to something, we can open a booth at Comic-Con, make a fortune.
Have you thought about putting him in a crate while you’re out of the apartment?
Gee. Why can’t Sheldon make friends?
Okay. 1, 2, 1, 2, 3 and… (Leonard, Howard and Raj whistle “Sweet Georgia Brown” together)
Me, me. Let it be me.
Oh come on. What do I have to do?
Suddenly I’m looking pretty good, huh?
You gotta give him credit for sticking with it.
Leonard: Ah, no kidding! A Fu Man Chu? A handlebar pencil?
Alright this is cruel, we better let him finish before his head explodes.
Hey Kripke.
Alright, please don’t cheer me up anymore.
Good luck getting time on it. The only people he lets use it are his friends.
There you go. Now any e-mail from Wolowitz will go right into your spam folder.
Yeah, I got the same one. And that’s not a bathing suit, it’s a tan line.
Oh he’s trying to make a new friend.
Well, unless he’s makes one out of wood like Gepetto, I don’t think it’s gonna happen.
There was a flier on the bulletin board at the university. Roommate wanted. Whistlers need not apply.
I assumed he was joking. You’d be surprised how many particle physicists have a whimsical side.
I don’t know, how do carbon atoms form a benzene ring? Proximity and valence electrons.
I suppose. I do miss whistling though.
I answered every question Sheldon.
Aw, you picked up on that huh?
Come on! There’s over 200 questions. And look at some of these things. Sheldon is to camaraderie, as the space shuttle is to blank?
Hold on. I put some real work into that!
It’s kinda cute, until you get to the scrotum.
Sheldon, I’m not going to defend a big-balled raccoon.
What I’m trying to say is that, maybe you can’t approach this as a purely intellectual exercise.
Well, remember when you tried to learn how to swim using the internet?
On the floor.
Then why learn how to swim?
No! no, my point is, if you want to learn how to make friends, then just go out to a coffee shop or a museum. Meet people. Talk to them. Take an interest in their lives.
Where are we going?
Why don’t you just lie down on the floor and swim there?
Okay, if you’re gonna start sniffing people, I’m gonna go get a hot pretzel.
Sheldon, what are you doing?
No you’re not, let’s go.
Don’t look up, there’s cameras.
Sheldon, there is no algorithm for making friends!
Yes, he’s new at the zoo.
Uh-oh, he’s stuck in an infinite loop.
I’m sorry. Can we please just do it one more time?
It’s a little thing but you really do miss it.
How was rock climbing?
Want some Chinese food?
In the bathroom.
What’s that?
Can I whistle?
He had Lysine but changed it.
I didn’t think he had it in him.
Kripke: Heard about your watest pwoton decay expewiment, twenty thousand data wuns and no statistically significant wesults. Vewy impwessive!
Yeah?
I would say, I have no intewest in becoming your fwiend.
Yeah, I’ll do that.
Nope, I wanna climb some wocks.
You afwaid of heights, Cooper?
Come on, they have birthday parties here. Wittle kids climb this.
Let’s go, Cooper.
Hey, look at you, Cooper. You’re almost halfway to the top.
You alwight there, Cooper?
Are you saying you’re stuck?
Understood all that. I’m not a mowon. Just keep going.
Well, then. Cwimb back down.
So what’s the pwan, Cooper?
Hewo to you, too.
He passed out. Just hung there like a big sawami.
Ooh, you have a special spot. What kind of wacko are you?
Tewific. Got any dental fwoss?
Be right back. I gotta fwoss the Indian food out of my teeth if I’m gonna eat Chinese.
I like to fwoss before I eat, so my gum pockets are open for new food.
Hewo. How did I walk past you? I’m Bawy.
Yeah, it’s not a vewy hot name. I’m gonna call your Woxanne. Ooh, pot stickers.
No.
I’m sowy. No, my fwiend?
No, that’s wong. There’s an official schedule. I have no contwol over it.
Penny: Thanks! I mean the e-mail doesn’t bother me as much as the vacation pictures of him in a bathing suit.
Oh really? Well, good for him.
Well, how did you guys become friends?
Well, what about Howard and Raj, I mean how did you become friends with them?
Well yeah, sure. When you put it that way. But it all worked out, right?
Yes. Well, that is a good question. But is this really the best way to figure it out?
Okay, question 1. Rank the following aspects of Sheldon Cooper in order of appeal. Intelligence. Ruthless attention to hygiene. Playfulness. Java applet writing?
Wait! How many questions are on this thing?
Sheldon honey, did you ever consider making friends by being, I don’t know, pleasant?
Okay. You know what? I see where this is going. I’m not one of you guys. I’m not a scientist. So just…
Sheldon (on phone): Hello. This is Sheldon Cooper. I’m leaving a message for Barry Kripke. Barry, It was pleasant seeing you today in the cafeteria. I saw that you purchased the chef’s salad. Apparently, you did not know that the chef’s salad is kitchen trickery, to utilize scrap meat. Nevertheless, I hope you enjoyed it. I’m following up on our pending friendship, and I look forward to hearing from you regarding its status. Sheldon Cooper.

Hello, Kripke. Yes, Sheldon Cooper here. It occurred to me you hadn’t returned any of my calls because I hadn’t offered any concrete suggestions for pursuing our friendship. Perhaps the two of us might share a meal together… I see. Well then perhaps you’d have time for a hot beverage. Popular choices include tea, coffee, cocoa… I see. No, no, no, wait. Don’t hang up yet. What about a recreational activity? I bet we share some common interests. Tell me an interest of yours. Really? On actual horses? Tell me another interest of yours. Oh no, I’m sorry, I have no desire to get in the water until I absolutely have to. Tell me another interest of yours.
Sheldon (Knock, knock, knock): Penny (knock, knock, knock)  Penny (knock, knock, knock)  Penny.This is for you.
Sheldon: There are a number of acceptabl: avocado rancher. And your essay, suggesting that I’d have better luck making friends if I wait ’til the Cylons take over? Please.
Bookstore employee: Um, yeah but they’re all for little kids.
Employee: Uh, I guess. They’re right over there by the wooden train set.
Sheldon (picks up train): Oh my! That’s awfully sticky. Alright, let’s see. Bernie Bunny has Two Daddies Now. It’s probably about homosexual rabbits. Jerry the Gerbil and the Bullies on the Bus. Read it, not helpful. Oh! Here we go. Stu the Cockatoo is New at the Zoo. Author Sarah Carpenter lives in Fort Wayne, Indiana, with her husband and best friend Mark, and their cockatoos too. Hardly makes her an expert in making friends, wouldn’t you agree?
Little girl: I don’t like birds, they scare me.

Oh really? Well, good for him.
Well, unless he’s makes one out of wood like Gepetto, I don’t think it’s gonna happen.
Well, how did you guys become friends?

I don’t know, how do carbon atoms form a benzene ring? Proximity and valence electrons.
Well yeah, sure. When you put it that way. But it all worked out, right?
I suppose. I do miss whistling though.
Penny (knock, knock, knock)  Penny (knock, knock, knock)  Penny.This is for you.
It’s a questionnaire I devised. I’m having some difficulty bonding with a colleague at work, so I’m doing a little research to better understand why my current friends like me.

Yeah, I agree, the social sciences are largely hokum. But, short of putting electrodes in your brain and monitoring your response to my companionship, this is the best I can do.
Okay, question 1. Rank the following aspects of Sheldon Cooper in order of appeal. Intelligence. Ruthless attention to hygiene. Playfulness. Java applet writing?

I know, I may have started off with a fairly obvious one. You did an aspect of my most appealing trait, playfulness. Why don’t you just go ahead and write that number 1. I’m afraid you’re on your own for the rest. It should take you no more than 3 hours.
Wait! How many questions are on this thing?
Only 211. Don’t worry, in deference to you, I’ve kept them on a high school graduate reading level.
Sheldon honey, did you ever consider making friends by being, I don’t know, pleasant?
Well that’s certainly a thought-provoking hypothesis. May I suggest it as the topic for your essay.
The apartment. Sheldon is reading one of the questionnaires. He tuts.
You answered the multiple choice questions in a pattern. A B B A C. A B B A C.
Aw, you picked up on that huh?
Come on! There’s over 200 questions. And look at some of these things. Sheldon is to camaraderie, as the space shuttle is to blank?
Sheldon: There are a number of acceptable answers, for example, C: near earth transport, but certainly not B
avocado rancher. And your essay, suggesting that I’d have better luck making friends if I wait ’til the Cylons take over? Please.
Hold on. I put some real work into that!
Yes, well it’s better than what Wolowitz did. He drew a raccoon with what appears to be, a distended scrotum.
It’s kinda cute, until you get to the scrotum.

Sheldon, I’m not going to defend a big-balled raccoon.
I don’t see how you could.

Well, remember when you tried to learn how to swim using the internet?
I did learn how to swim.
The skills are transferrable. I just have no interest in going in the water.
Then why learn how to swim?

The ice caps are melting Leonard. In the future, swimming isn’t going to be optional. But you do bring up an interesting point. I don’t have to break new ground here, I’m sure much of the research already exists.
No! no, my point is, if you want to learn how to make friends, then just go out to a coffee shop or a museum. Meet people. Talk to them. Take an interest in their lives.
That’s insane on the face of it. Come on.
You’re driving me to the mall. I’m going to acquire a book that summarizes the current theories in the field of friendmaking.
Why don’t you just lie down on the floor and swim there?
Coping with the death of a loved one. My condolences.
Too bad. If it’d been a friend, I’m available to fill the void. (Woman moves away) It’s just as well, she smelled like moth balls.
Okay, if you’re gonna start sniffing people, I’m gonna go get a hot pretzel.
Excuse me. Do you have any books about making friends?
Um, yeah but they’re all for little kids.
I assume the skills can be extrapolated and transferred.
Uh, I guess. They’re right over there by the wooden train set.

Oh my! That’s awfully sticky. Alright, let’s see. Bernie Bunny has Two Daddies Now. It’s probably about homosexual rabbits. Jerry the Gerbil and the Bullies on the Bus. Read it, not helpful. Oh! Here we go. Stu the Cockatoo is New at the Zoo. Author Sarah Carpenter lives in Fort Wayne, Indiana, with her husband and best friend Mark, and their cockatoos too. Hardly makes her an expert in making friends, wouldn’t you agree?
I don’t like birds, they scare me.
Me too! Most people don’t see it. What are you reading?
Somewhat anthropomorphized but yes. Say, maybe sometime you and I can go see monkeys together. Would you like that?
I’m making friends with this little girl. What’s your name?
Hi Rebecca, I’m your new friend, Sheldon.
We were really hitting it off.
I’m curious. In the “How Well Do You Know Sheldon” section, what do you put for his favourite amino acid?
Damn it. I had Lysine and changed it.
Oh good! You’re just in time. I believe I’ve isolated the algorithm for making friends.
Sheldon, there is no algorithm for making friends!
Hear him out. If he’s really on to something, we can open a booth at Comic-Con, make a fortune.
See, my initial approach to Kripke, had the same deficiencies as those that plagued Stu the Cockatoo, when he was new at the zoo.
Yes, he’s new at the zoo.

Have you thought about putting him in a crate while you’re out of the apartment?

I’m surprised you saw that.
Gee. Why can’t Sheldon make friends?

Alright Kripke, that last interest strikes me as the least objectionable and I would like to propose that we do that together. Tomorrow. Yes, I’ll pay. Alright, goodbye. Alright! Time to learn rock climbing.

Understood all that. I’m not a mowon. Just keep going.
Yeah, I don’t think I can.
No, that doesn’t seem any more likely.
Well, it’s not exactly a plan but I think I’m going to pass out.
I’m sorry. Can we please just do it one more time?
Okay. 1, 2, 1, 2, 3 and… (Leonard, Howard and Raj whistle “Sweet Georgia Brown” together)
It’s a little thing but you really do miss it.

He passed out. Just hung there like a big sawami.

Sheldon is seen dangling from the ropes
